page.title: 08The Northgate
page.content: The Northgate is the only relic left to Bridgnorth of the Old Town. It is a stone Gate-House. It is not known when it was built. A Norman Arch connected with the Gateway, but this had been hidden by other buildings until 1821, when it was demolished to make room for some more buildings. Now in 1985, there is a Museum over the Northgate. Small vehicles are able to travel under the Gateway and on one side, there is a restaurant and on the other a shop. In 1645, on May 21st., Colonel Billingsley was ordered to bring soldiers and ammunition to the Northgate to fortify it. The Parliamentary Forces from Shrewsbury came via the Broseley Road and were unable to enter the Town Via the Northgate. Shortly afterwards, the same soldier was killed in attempting to defend St. Leonards Church.
